title-group.article-title: Performance of International Classification of Disease-10 codes in detecting emergency department patients with opioid misuse

sec.title: Background and Aims:
sec.p: Accurate case discovery is critical for disease surveillance, resource allocation and research. International Classification of Disease (ICD) diagnosis codes are commonly used for this purpose. We aimed to determine the sensitivity, specificity and positive predictive value (PPV) of ICD-10 codes for opioid misuse case discovery in the emergency department (ED) setting.

sec.title: Design and Setting:
sec.p: Retrospective cohort study of ED encounters from January 2018 to December 2020 at an urban academic hospital in the United States. A sample of ED encounters enriched for opioid misuse was developed by oversampling ED encounters with positive urine opiate screens or pre-existing opioid-related diagnosis codes in addition to other opioid misuse risk factors.

sec.title: Cases:
sec.p: A total of 1200 randomly selected encounters were annotated by research staff for the presence of opioid misuse within health record documentation using a 5-point scale for likelihood of opioid misuse and dichotomized into cohorts of opioid misuse and no opioid misuse.

sec.title: Measurements:
sec.p: Using manual annotation as ground truth, the sensitivity and specificity of ICD-10 codes entered during the encounter were determined with PPV adjusted for oversampled data. Metrics were also determined by disposition subgroup: discharged home or admitted.

sec.title: Findings:
sec.p: There were 541 encounters annotated as opioid misuse and 617 with no opioid misuse. The majority were males (54.4%), average age was 47 years and 68.5% were discharged directly from the ED. The sensitivity of ICD-10 codes was 0.56 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.51–0.60), specificity 0.99 (95% CI, 0.97–0.99) and adjusted PPV 0.78 (95% CI, 0.65–0.92). The sensitivity was higher for patients discharged from the ED (0.65; 95% CI, 0.60–0.69) than those admitted (0.31; 95% CI, 0.24–0.39).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: International Classification of Disease-10 codes appear to have low sensitivity but high specificity and positive predictive value in detecting opioid misuse among emergency department patients in the United States.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Opioid misuse, defined as the use of illegal opioids or the use of prescription opioids in a manner other than as directed by a doctor, is a public health emergency in the United States with opioids accounting for over 80 000 deaths in 2021 [1, 2]. The emergency department (ED) represents a common contact point between patients that misuse opioids and the broader healthcare system. As the ED is a common entry point for the initiation of therapies and referral for continued treatment, it is critical that opioid misuse is identified accurately and consistently to offer these services [3, 4]. Similarly, the accurate documentation of opioid-related ED encounters is important for disease surveillance, healthcare resource allocation and cohort discovery for research purposes.

Diagnostic codes entered by clinicians represent a common data point for the determination of the prevalence of opioid-related ED encounters [5–8]. International Classification of Disease (ICD) diagnostic codes are seen by the World Health Organization as ‘a common language for recording, reporting and monitoring diseases’. [9] Research often relies on the accurate entry of ICD-10 codes for the development of disease cohorts. The sensitivity of these codes in accurately identifying all cases of many disease processes have been found to be low, with specificity and positive predictive values (PPVs) typically higher [10–12]. Diagnosis codes for opioid use, dependence and abuse have been found to be poor surrogate markers for opioid use disorder and fail to capture many cases of opioid use disorder in the outpatient setting [13, 14]. The diagnostic accuracy of ICD-10 codes representing behavior encompassing opioid misuse in the ED setting is yet unknown. These include codes for poisoning, intoxication, withdrawal and adverse events. Quantifying the use of ICD-10 codes in identifying cases of opioid misuse in the ED setting will affect the interpretation of ED-based research and ED resource allocation decisions within health systems, which commonly use ICD-10 codes to identify patients with opioid misuse.

The objective of the current study was to determine the sensitivity, specificity and PPV of ICD-10 codes for opioid misuse within the ED setting. We hypothesize that, similar to other disease processes, ICD-10 codes have limited sensitivity, but adequate specificity and PPV for the identification of opioid misuse in ED patients. These hypotheses were not preregistered, and results should, therefore, be considered exploratory.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: This is a retrospective cohort study of ED encounters at an urban academic hospital between January 2018 and December 2020. A sample of ED encounters enriched for suspected opioid misuse was developed using previously described methods involving sampling ED encounters with a positive urine opiate screen without coexisting opioid prescription on hospital intake or a pre-existing opioid-related ICD-10 diagnostic code and matching with encounters lacking those criteria [15]. We chose to enrich the sample for opioid misuse to account for the relatively small number of ED encounters involving opioid misuse when compared to the total of all ED encounters. All ED encounters matching the stated criteria during the study period were identified and then matched 1:1 on disposition status (admission vs discharge) from the ED with encounters not matching any of the previously described criteria or additional criteria placing the patient at risk for opioid misuse including chronic pain ICD-10 diagnosis codes, an ED order for naloxone or order for a urine drug screen regardless of results. Although a chronic pain diagnosis does not imply opioid misuse, these were included as patients with chronic pain are at increased risk for substance use disorders and comprised 5.9% of the final sample [16, 17]. Ultimate classification of opioid misuse was based on manual annotation and not chronic pain diagnoses as described below. Matching on disposition was done in lieu of age and sex to minimize bias from potential enhanced documentation, testing and entry of ICD-10 diagnosis codes based on ultimate admission status and because age and sex were potentially important predictors for opioid misuse. This resulted in a sample of 8372 ED encounters, from which 1200 were randomly selected for manual chart annotation and analysis. Forty-two encounters were subsequently excluded because of restrictions indicating enhanced privacy measures in the medical record.

Encounters were manually annotated by reviewing clinical documentation for the presence of opioid misuse using a previously validated method based on National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH) and the National Institute of Drug Abuse (NIDA) definition for opioid misuse: Individuals taking an opioid for reason other than prescribed or as an illicit drug [2, 15, 18, 19]. Trained annotators performed a review of clinical data and notes for each patient encounter in the electronic health record (EHR) to provide a determination for the likelihood of behavior consistent with opioid misuse on a 5-point Likert scale (1–5). The scale included the following categories for the likelihood of opioid misuse based on the NSDUH and NIDA definition: (1) definitely; (2) highly probable; (3) probable; (4) definitely not; and (5) uncertain. Probable encounters included documentation of any of the following: history of opioid misuse without current documentation; mention of drug-seeking behavior in clinical documentation; evidence of other non-alcohol substance misuse along with prescription or illicit opioid use; or history of opioid misuse in remission, but patient remains at risk. Highly probable encounters were those with more than one of the ‘probable’ criteria or a diagnosis of opioid dependence with suspicion of opioid misuse in the clinical notes without evidence. Definite encounters of opioid misuse included those with a self-report of opioid misuse by the patient or documentation by the clinician of opioid misuse. This scale was dichotomized to positive and negative encounters for analysis (definitely, highly probable and probable as positive; definitely not and uncertain as negative). Only five encounters (0.4%) were categorized as ‘uncertain’ and the primary outcomes of sensitivity, specificity and PPV were robust to sensitivity analyses, which excluded these encounters (Appendix S1). Chart annotators were trained on the NIDA/NSDUH definition for opioid misuse and how to identify and annotate the charts from information within the EHR. They independently annotated charts only after achieving adequate interrater agreement on overlapping encounters with an ED physician and substance use researcher, as evidenced by a Cohen’s κ score of >0.75. Following every hundred annotated encounters, annotators again reviewed an overlap of encounters to prevent drift and reconfirm adequate interrater agreement.

Using manual annotation labels as ground truth, the sensitivity, specificity and PPV of ICD-10 codes for the detection of opioid misuse were determined with exact binomial 95% confidence intervals (CI). Sensitivity and specificity were defined in the context of the current study as the ratio of true positives identified by ICD-10 codes to all positives identified by ground truth manual annotation labels and the ratio of true negatives by ICD-10 codes to all negatives by manual annotation labels. These measures are, therefore, measuring the sensitivity and specificity of ICD-10 codes against manual chart annotations. Adjusted PPV was computed using Mercaldo et al.’s [20–22] method for oversampled data accounting for true prevalence estimated at 6%. True prevalence was estimated using previously reported manual screening results for opioid misuse among admitted patients at the primary institution. This was extrapolated to the ED setting using the ratio of admitted to discharged ED patient encounters with opioid-related disorders or poisoning by drugs in the state of Illinois derived from the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality and Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) [6, 21, 23]. The ICD-10 codes used were derived from HCUP (Appendix S2) [24]. To evaluate differences based on ED disposition, metrics were also determined for subgroups based on disposition status from the ED (discharged home or admitted to the hospital). Demographic differences between groups were compared using χ2 test of independence. Analyses were performed using R (version 4.2.2, package: epiR) [25, 26]. This study was approved by the institutional review board of Rush University Medical Center. This study conforms, where applicable, to the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology statement guidelines (Appendix S3) [27].

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: A total of 541 patient encounters (46.7% of sample) met criteria for opioid misuse following manual annotation. Demographic information and ED disposition are shown in Table 1. The total sample consisted of patient encounters that were predominantly male and had public insurance (Medicaid or Medicare). Differences between encounters with behaviors consistent with opioid misuse and those without opioid misuse included a higher proportion of male sex (70.8% vs 40.0%, P < 0.001), non-Hispanic ethnicity (97.0% vs 92.2%, P < 0.001), White race (33.1% vs 22.8%, P < 0.001) and Medicaid insurance (60.1% vs 38.1%, P < 0.001).

The sensitivity of ICD-10 codes entered during the encounter consistent with opioid misuse was 0.56 (95% CI, 0.51–0.60), specificity was 0.99 (95% CI, 0.97–0.99) and PPV was 0.97 (95% CI, 0.95–0.99). Correcting for prevalence of disease, the PPV decreased to 0.78 (95% CI, 0.65–0.92). On subgroup analysis, diagnostic metrics were better for patient encounters discharged from the ED than for those admitted to the hospital (Table 2).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: These findings indicate that the sensitivity of ICD-10 codes is poor for detecting ED patients with behaviors consistent with opioid misuse. The same codes, in contrast, show high specificity and acceptable PPV when present. The use of ICD-10 codes to retrospectively identify patient encounters from the ED with opioid misuse is insensitive and likely to miss numerous patient encounters with opioid misuse. This carries implications for both local health system monitoring and broader research aims. Analyses that use ICD-10 codes to identify ED patient encounters with opioid misuse should recognize this limitation and adjust analyses accordingly or seek alternative approaches for cohort identification that are not reliant on diagnostic codes [15, 28, 29].

The use of ICD-10 codes to retrospectively identify opioid misuse is common in research [3, 6, 30–33]. Using this approach, Langabeer et al. [6] found that there were ~1.44 million unique opioid-related ED encounters with charges approaching $5 billion annually in the years 2016 and 2017 using ICD-10 codes from a large nationally representative registry as the primary method of detection. Our findings suggest that these figures are likely drastic underestimations of the true burden of disease in the ED setting. Previous ED-based research has highlighted the poor sensitivity of diagnostic codes to detect overdose from opioids more specifically. Rowe et al. [7] noted a 56.8% sensitivity using ICD-9 codes from 2012 to 2014 to detect opioid overdose. The current results suggest that not only has the sensitivity continued to be poor for opioid-related diagnoses in the ED following the migration to ICD-10 codes, but that it remains poor when expanded to include non-overdose reasons for ED presentation. The sensitivity of ICD-10 codes for opioid misuse was lower for encounters resulting in hospital admission compared to those discharged from the ED. This carries important implications for estimations of opioid-related hospital admissions using billing data. The cause of this discrepancy is unknown, but one contributing factor could be that those with obvious opioid-related emergencies, such as overdose, are more likely to be discharged from the ED and those admitted may have a non-opioid indication for admission with opioid misuse merely as a contributing factor. As such, documentation of opioid misuse via ICD-10 code may be lacking in this scenario. Further research is needed to confirm or refute this phenomenon and explore its root causes.

Illicit substance use worsens numerous disease processes and may lead to poor health outcomes following an ED encounter, whether directly or indirectly attributed to opioid misuse. Additionally, most patients with untreated opioid use disorder presenting to the ED do not present with the primary intent to actively seek referral for treatment [34]. As such, accurate detection of opioid misuse is critical even for those with a healthcare encounter seemingly unrelated to substance misuse. Screening based approaches offer one option to improve opioid misuse detection, but is resource intensive [35]. Automated approaches using machine learning offer another method to improve detection and documentation of opioid misuse [15, 28]. Diagnosis codes are one way health systems estimate burdens of disease and decide how best to allocate needed resources. As ED-based interventions including buprenorphine initiation, peer-recovery coaches and warm handoffs to outpatient opioid use disorder care have expanded in recent years, the accurate detection of patients with opioid misuse is key to identify all patients that may potentially benefit from these resources [36–38].

There are several limitations to the current study. First, the study represents findings from a single center. Illicit drug use has geographic variability both in types of drugs used and methods of use and coding practices may vary across centers. As such, these results may not be representative of other practice locations within the United States. Second, the use of an enriched sampling design may skew findings. As pre-existing ICD-10 codes were used as one part of the criteria to identify potential encounters involving opioid misuse, this represents a form of selection bias that may artificially overestimate the sensitivity of ICD-10 codes reported here. Third, blinded abstractors were able to identify opioid-related diagnosis codes during their manual annotation process, which may bias their determination. Manual annotation relied on clinical documentation that may not always be accurate. Finally, ICD-10 codes are typically used for billing purposes and contain minimal information when compared to clinical documentation. The absence of specific ICD-10 codes does not necessarily indicate that a certain clinical condition was not detected, but merely that it was not entered or was considered irrelevant for billing purposes.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: ICD-10 codes had a low sensitivity, but high specificity and PPV in detecting opioid misuse among ED patient encounters. The use of ICD-10 codes to identify or quantify cases of opioid misuse from ED encounters should be done with caution and analyses should account for this low sensitivity.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from Rush University Medical Center (RUMC). Restrictions apply to the availability of these data, which were used under license for this study. Data are available from RUMC with the permission of RUMC.

caption.p: Diagnostic metrics of ICD-10 code for opioid misuse.
